Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: The planning session is informal, and the timeline can still shift without major impact
Story: I glanced at my calendar and felt my stomach tighten. The team meeting was about to start, and as a colleague, I knew how important it was to be present. These meetings were the only place where project updates were shared, and missing one meant being out of the loop. My teammates expected me to show up, contribute, and stay connected. But at the same time, my lead engineer pinged me, asking for my input on the project planning session happening right now. They needed my expertise to estimate timelines, and even though the session was informal and the deadlines weren’t set in stone, I knew my input would shape the next steps. I could feel the pressure mounting—if I skipped the meeting, I’d let my colleagues down and risk missing crucial information. If I ignored the planning session, I’d delay the engineering team and possibly throw off our workflow. My mind raced, torn between being a reliable teammate and a responsible engineer, wishing I could split myself in two.
